bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Francis Lee, May 11, 1706

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant Francis Lee, May 11, 1706, that he is enclosing a bill of lading for 12 hogsheads of tobacco belonging to the estate of Ralph Wormeley on board the America, and another for tobacco on board the Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Francis Lee, May 11, 1706

opener.dateline:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
May 11: 1706
Mr. Fra Lee.

div1.p:
This covers a Bill of Lading for 12 [hogsheads of tobacco]
on board the America Capt Silvester belong[ing to the estate]
of Esqr Wormly also a Bill of Lading for [21 hogsheads also the]
Estates Tobo. in the Carter Capt [Thomas] Graves being [all I]
have of tht concern this year have not time
at present I think to be particular here [in]
the Interim Sr

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, Processioners' Returns, 1711-1783, and Wormeley Estate Papers, 1701-1710, 1716, Acc. 30126, Archives Research Services, Library of Virginia, Richmond, 169.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and state have been added for clarity.

[1] A vessel named the Carter traded to Virginia for many years; she is most often referred to as the Carter Frigatt. The captain in 1706 was Thomas Graves who is mentioned in the Lancaster County Court Orders Book for judgements against him obtained by RC. Later, the Carter would be commanded by Baily Kent, 1718-1721, Thomas Dove, and by Benjamin Graves. She was owned by RC and William Dawkins in 1720. (Survey report 6800 for Adm. 68/194-5, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia; and Lancaster County Court Orders Book 5, 1702-13, p. 187, as abstracted in Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . . " )
